CheckerboardÂ¶

Mathematically we can define a basic checkerboard as follows:

\[\begin{split}checkerboard(x, y) = \begin{cases} white, \text{ if } xy > 0 \\ black, \text{ otherwise} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

where \(x, y \in [-1, 1]\) Which we can write in python as such:

from mage.image import make_img
from mage.coords import cartesian


@cartesian(X=[-1, 1], Y=[-1, 1])
def checker(x, y):

    if x * y > 0:
        return (255, 255, 255)
    else:
        return (128, 128, 128)


img = make_img(512, 512, checker, 'checker.png')

Which gives us the result below:

However, it would be good if we could alter the size of the squares. We can do this by extending the function we defined above. If we periodically extend the function, then any time we deviate from the original domain, we shift the value so that it has the same relative offset in the original domain. For example if we are given a value of \(1.5\), it’s outside the interval \([-1,1]\) so we shift it left by the length of the interval - which in this case is 2 and that gives us the final value of -0.5.

By defining the checkerboard in this way allows us to keep the nice simple definition we started with and control the size of the square by simply mapping the extended function onto larger/smaller domains. In Python we write this as:

from mage.image import make_img
from mage.coords import cartesian, extend_periodically


@cartesian(X=[-4, 4], Y=[-4, 4])  # Changing these values affect the grid size
@extend_periodically(X=[-1, 1], Y=[-1, 1])
def checker(x, y):

    if x * y > 0:
        return (255, 255, 255)
    else:
        return (128, 128, 128)


img = make_img(512, 512, scaled_checker, 'scaled_checker.png')
